lines.text: Enter three Watchmen, to guard KING EDWARD IV's tent

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Come on, my masters, each man take his stand: The king by this is set him down to sleep.

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: What, will he not to bed?

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Why, no; for he hath made a solemn vow Never to lie and take his natural rest Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: To-morrow then belike shall be the day, If Warwick be so near as men report.

lines.speaker: third watchman
lines.text: But say, I pray, what nobleman is that That with the king here resteth in his tent?

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: 'Tis the Lord Hastings, the king's chiefest friend.

lines.speaker: third watchman
lines.text: O, is it so? But why commands the king That his chief followers lodge in towns about him, While he himself keeps in the cold field?

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: 'Tis the more honour, because more dangerous.

lines.speaker: third watchman
lines.text: Ay, but give me worship and quietness; I like it better than a dangerous honour. If Warwick knew in what estate he stands, 'Tis to be doubted he would waken him.

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Unless our halberds did shut up his passage.

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: Ay, wherefore else guard we his royal tent, But to defend his person from night-foes?
Enter WARWICK, CLARENCE, OXFORD, SOMERSET, and French soldiers, silent all

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: This is his tent; and see where stand his guard. Courage, my masters! honour now or never! But follow me, and Edward shall be ours.

lines.speaker: first watchman
lines.text: Who goes there?

lines.speaker: second watchman
lines.text: Stay, or thou diest! WARWICK and the rest cry all, 'Warwick! Warwick!'  and set upon the Guard, who fly, crying, 'Arm! arm!' WARWICK and the rest following them
The drum playing and trumpet sounding, reenter  WARWICK, SOMERSET, and the rest, bringing KING  EDWARD IV out in his gown, sitting in a chair. RICHARD and HASTINGS fly over the stage

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: What are they that fly there?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Richard and Hastings: let them go; here is The duke.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: The duke! Why, Warwick, when we parted, Thou call'dst me king.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Ay, but the case is alter'd: When you disgraced me in my embassade, Then I degraded you from being king, And come now to create you Duke of York. Alas! how should you govern any kingdom, That know not how to use ambassadors, Nor how to be contented with one wife, Nor how to use your brothers brotherly, Nor how to study for the people's welfare, Nor how to shroud yourself from enemies?

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Yea, brother of Clarence, are thou here too? Nay, then I see that Edward needs must down. Yet, Warwick, in despite of all mischance, Of thee thyself and all thy complices, Edward will always bear himself as king: Though fortune's malice overthrow my state, My mind exceeds the compass of her wheel.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Then, for his mind, be Edward England's king: But Henry now shall wear the English crown, And be true king indeed, thou but the shadow. My Lord of Somerset, at my request, See that forthwith Duke Edward be convey'd Unto my brother, Archbishop of York. When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows, I'll follow you, and tell what answer Lewis and the Lady Bona send to him. Now, for a while farewell, good Duke of York.
Takes off his crown
They lead him out forcibly

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: What fates impose, that men must needs abide; It boots not to resist both wind and tide.
Exit, guarded

lines.speaker: oxford
lines.text: What now remains, my lords, for us to do But march to London with our soldiers?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Ay, that's the first thing that we have to do; To free King Henry from imprisonment And see him seated in the regal throne.
Exeunt
